item.title: Maven Versioning Strategy
item.description: I’ve been having a lot of discussions with analysts in my organization about how to version software using Maven and I’m finding there is a common misconception about what SNAPSHOT actually means. I’ve been looking for a good blog to send them that helps explain versioning in Maven but unfortunately everything I’ve found merely discusses version formats and not how to use them as you’re developing an application. So, I decided I would take a stab at it. I welcome any comments and constructive criticism that will help me improve this document, so please feel free. First off, a SNAPSHOT is not the same thing as an alpha/beta/etc version. It is a special keyword that means it is the latest version of your code. This means it changes. If you pulled down someapp-1.0-SNAPSHOT yesterday and then you try to pull it down today it will most likely not be the same. This also means if you have a project dependent on a SNAPSHOT version, maven will need to check the remote repository for changes every time you run a build.
